coauthors.bio: Aharon Varady, founding director of the Open Siddur Project, is a copyright researcher and amateur book scanner. He prepares digital images and new digital editions of prayer books and related works in the Public Domain in order to make their constituent parts (prayers, translations, annotations, etc.) publicly accessible for collaborative transcription by project volunteers. (In some cases, he finds existing digital editions prepared by others that require correction and reformatting.) If you appreciate his efforts, please send him a kind note or contribute to his patreon account.

If you know more, or can provide a reference to an article or book providing additional information, please contact us.

◊û÷∑◊ó÷≤◊ñ◊ï÷π◊® ◊ú÷∞◊®◊ê÷π◊©◊Å ◊î÷∑◊©◊Å÷∏◊†÷∏◊î Majzor leRosh Hashanah (1976) is the first edition of a bilingual Hebrew-Spanish nusa·∏• Sefaradi Rosh haShanah prayerbook compiled and translated by Rabbi Meir Matslia·∏• Melamed (1920-1989). Rabbi Melamed had in 1971 been installed at the pulpit of the Cuban Sephardic Hebrew Congregation, after having served previously in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil where his 1966 Hebrew-Portuguese siddur Tefilat Maslia·∏• was first published. For both prayerbooks, as no Hebrew type with vocalization and cantillation marks was available to Rabbi Melamed, liturgy was reproduced from images of older siddurim. Rabbi Melamed’s translation appears to the sides of these images and his commentary underneath.

This work is in the Public Domain as it was published in the United States within 30 days of having been published in a foreign country. Additionally, the work is in the Public Domain for not having been registered with the US Copyright Office, a required condition for works published before 1 January 1978.

Source (Spanish) Translation (English)
SIGNIFICADO DE ROSH HASHANA
Significance of Rosh haShanah
Selijot ‚Äî Los d√≠as a partir del mes de Elul hasta el 1¬∞ de Tishri, son llamados ‚ÄúYem√© Haselijot‚Äù, d√≠as de piedades y perd√≥n: Esto significa que, aunque Dios perdona los pecados a penticencia, estos d√≠as son los m√°s propicios de todo a√±o para el arrepentimiento y para recibir la benevolencia y misericordia de Dios.
Seli·∏•ot ‚Äî The days from the month of Elul until the 1st of Tishri are called ‚ÄúYemei Haseli·∏•ot,‚Äù days of supplication and forgiveness. This means that, although God forgives sins upon repentance, these days are the most auspicious of the entire year for repentance and for receiving God’s benevolence and mercy.
Seg√∫n la Biblia, el 1¬∞ de Elul subi√≥ Moises por tercera vez al Monte Sinai, para recibir las segundas tablas de la Ley, y all√≠ permaneci√≥ cuarenta d√≠as y cuarenta noches, al cabo de los cuales regres√≥ con las nuevas tablas y con el perd√≥n de Dios por el pecado del ‚ÄúBecerro de Oro‚Äù. Estos cuarenta d√≠as los israelitas de aquel tiempo los pasaron entregados al examen de sus conciencias y al arrepentimiento, hasta el √∫ltmio d√≠a (10 de Tishri) que es Yom Kipur.
According to the Bible, on the 1st of Elul, Moses ascended Mount Sinai for the third time to receive the second tablets of the Law, and remained there for forty days and forty nights, after which he returned with the new tablets and God’s forgiveness for the sin of the ‚ÄúGolden Calf.‚Äù The Israelites of that time spent these forty days examining their consciences and repenting, until the last day (10 Tishri), which is Yom Kippur.
De acuerdo con la Tradici√≥n, esos cua renta d√≠as, a partir de la luna nueva de Elul, son un per√≠odo de gracia para el hombre que, mediante el arrepentimiento de sus pecados, conquista el perd√≥n que Dios le otorgar√° en Yom Kipur.
According to tradition, these forty days, beginning with the new moon of Elul, are a period of grace for man who, through repentance for his sins, earns the forgiveness that God will grant him on Yom Kippur.
Por eso, durante el mes de Elul, se incluyen los Selijot, preces invocadoras del perd√≥n, que se rezan en las madrugadas, desde el segundo d√≠a de Elul hasta el 9 de Tishri, excluyendo las madrugadas de los dos d√≠as de Rosh Hashan√°.
For this reason, during the month of Elul, Selichot, prayers invoking forgiveness, are included and recited in the early morning hours from the second day of Elul until the 9th of Tishri, excluding the early morning hours of the two days of Rosh Hashanah.
YAMIM NORAIM
 
Rosh Hashan√°, d√≠a del a√±o nuevo, y Yom Kipur, d√≠a del perd√≥n, son las fiestas austeras, (Yamin Noraim), del calendario hebreo. No hay en ellas evocaiones hist√≥ricas como es el caso en Pesaj, Shavuot y Sucot, ni recuerdos e la vida agr√≠cola de Erez Yisrael. Son festidades puramente religiosas, destinadas a poner al individuo frente al tribunal del juez Supremo, Dios, y de su propia conciencia. Los sentimientos que prevalecen en Rosh Hashan√° y Yom Kipur son la seriedad, la reverencia y la austeridad, en contraste con las dem√°s Fiestas Biblicas, celebradas con alegr√≠a y j√∫bilo. La Penitencia, La Oraci√≥n y la Caridad, hacen anular, particularmente en estos d√≠as, las sentencias severas en contra de nosotros.
Rosh Hashanah, New Year’s Day, and Yom Kippur, Day of Atonement, are the austere holidays (Yamin Noraim) of the Hebrew calendar. They do not involve historical commemorations, as is the case with Passover, Shavuot, and Sukkot, nor do they evoke memories of the agricultural life of Erets Yisrael. They are purely religious holidays, intended to bring the individual before the court of the Supreme Judge, God, and his own conscience. The prevailing sentiments on Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur are seriousness, reverence, and austerity, in contrast to the other Biblical holidays, which are celebrated with joy and jubilation. Penance, prayer, and charity, particularly on these days, nullify the severe judgments against us.
ROSH HASHANA
Rosh haShanah
Rosh Hashan√° es el nombre que se le da en nuestra literatura al a√±o nuevo y se celebra a√∫n en Eretz Yisrael el primero y e segundo d√≠as de Tishri, por causa de que exist√≠a siempre la duda en qu√© d√≠a el Sanhedrin (Tribunal Religioso) de aquellos tiempos fijar√≠a esta fiesta. Ros Hashan√° es una de las m√°s sagradas fechas de la fe judaica y da inicio a los diez d√≠as de penitencia, cuando la humanidad se somete al juicio frente al Trono Celestial. Durante este per√≠odo, afirma la tradici√≥n, Dios analiza los corazones de los hombres y examina sus actos. Es tambi√©n un per√≠odo en que los jud√≠os se juzgan a s√≠ mismos comparando sus procedimientos del a√±o terminado con las resoluciones tomadas y las esperanzas que hab√≠an forjado.
Rosh Hashanah is the name given in our literature to the New Year, and it is still celebrated in Erets Yisrael on the first and second days of Tishri, because there was always uncertainty as to which day the Sanhedrin (Religious Court) of those times would set for this holiday. Rosh Hashanah is one of the holiest dates in the Jewish faith and marks the beginning of the ten days of penance, when humanity is judged before the Heavenly Throne. During this period, tradition holds, God analyzes the hearts of men and examines their deeds. It is also a period when Jews judge themselves by comparing their actions during the past year with the resolutions they had made and the hopes they had forged.
Los nombres dados en la Biblia a la fiesta de Rosh Hashan√° son: Yom Teru√° (D√≠a del sonido del shof√°r) y Zijron Teru√° (D√≠a de la recordaci√≥n del sonido del shof√°r). En nuestra liturgia se le llama tambi√©n Yom Hazicaron (D√≠a del recuerdo) y Yom Haddin (D√≠a del juicio) significando que debemos recordar en este d√≠a nuestras responsabilidades frente a Dios y a nosotros mismos, en nuestra vida privada y p√∫blica, mejorar nuestras acciones y presentarnos as√≠ ante el Tribunal de Dios.
The names given in the Bible to the feast of Rosh Hashanah are: Yom Teruah (Day of the Sound of the Shofar) and Zikhron Teruah (Day of Remembrance of the Sound of the Shofar). In our liturgy, it is also called Yom Hazikaron (Day of Remembrance) and Yom HaDin (Day of Judgment), meaning that on this day we must remember our responsibilities before God and ourselves, in our private and public lives, improve our actions, and thus present ourselves before the Tribunal of God.
El s√≠mbolo m√°s importante de las pr√°cticas de Rosh Hashan√° es el shof√°r, o cuerno de carnero, que se toca durante el culto del a√±o nuevo y en los diez d√≠as de penitencia. En los oficios de Rosh Hashan√°, el toque del shof√°r ed el llamado a la adoraci√≥n. Incita a los fieles a ar repentirse de sus faltas en el a√±o transcurrido, volver a Dios con el esp√≠ritu contrito y humilde, a distinguir entre lo trivial y lo importante en la vida, para que el a√±o siguiente pueda ser m√°s rico en buenas acciones.
The most important symbol of Rosh Hashanah practices is the shofar, or ram’s horn, which is blown during the New Year’s service and during the ten days of penance. In Rosh Hashanah services, the blowing of the shofar is a call to worship. It urges the faithful to repent for their sins in the past year, to return to God with a contrite and humble spirit, to distinguish between the trivial and the important in life, so that the coming year may be richer in good deeds.
El ritual del toque del shof√°r comprende tres partes:
The ritual of blowing the shofar consists of three parts:
1‚Äî MALJUYOT, que es el principio de la existencia de Dios y la proclamaci√≥n de la realeza divina.
1‚Äî MALKHUYOT, which is the principle of God’s existence and the proclamation of divine kingship.
2 ‚Äî ZIKHRONOT, que es el principio de la recompensa y el castigo y de la inmortalidad del alma. Que Dios lo sabe todo, lo ve todo y lo recuerda todo. Tambi√©n nos trae a la memoria las promesas divinas, el pacto de Dios con Israel, as√≠ como el sacrificio de Isaac.
2 ‚Äî ZIKHRONOT, which is the principle of reward and punishment and the immortality of the soul. That God knows everything, sees everything, and remembers everything. It also brings to mind the divine promises, God’s covenant with Yisrael, and the sacrifice of Yits·∏•aq.
3 ‚ÄîSHOFAROT, el principio de la revelaci√≥n, el eco del Sina√≠, la se√±al de la resurrecci√≥n, el despertar de la humanidad.
3 ‚ÄîSHOFAROT, the beginning of revelation, the echo of Sinai, the sign of resurrection, the awakening of humanity.
Los m√≠sticos afirman que el toque del shof√°r se destina a confundir al propio ‚ÄúEsp√≠ritu del Mal‚Äù y recordar a la persona que se deja guiar por √©ste, lo que sufrir√° en el juicio final, al ser condenado por sus malas acciones.
Mystics claim that the blowing of the shofar is intended to confuse the ‚ÄúSpirit of Evil‚Äù itself and remind those who are guided by it of what they will suffer in the final judgment, when they will be condemned for their evil deeds.
El universo fue creado en Rosh Hashan√°. Celebrando el aniversario de la creaci√≥n del mundo, reconocemos y proclamamos al Supremo Creador como Rey del Mundo.
The universe was created on Rosh Hashanah. By celebrating the anniversary of the creation of the world, we acknowledge and proclaim the Supreme Creator as King of the World.
La solemnidad del 1¬∞ de Tishri debe ser no s√≥lo la del comienzo del a√±o, sino tambi√©n la del comienzo del hombre, pues por medio de la expiaci√≥n y del perd√≥n divino, el hombre renace en cierto modo a la vida y recibe un coraz√≥n nuevo un alma nueva. En los sacrificios de las dem√°s festividades fue escrito ‚Äúvehikravtem‚Äù (y ofrecer√©is) pero en el de Rosh Hashan√°, ‚Äúvaasitem‚Äù, (y har√©is) para ense√±arnos que en este d√≠ la sagrado debemos hacer el sacrificio de nuestro propio ser.
The solemnity of the 1st of Tishri should be not only that of the beginning of the year, but also that of the beginning of man, for through atonement and divine forgiveness, man is in a sense reborn to life and receives a new heart and a new soul. In the sacrifices of the other festivals it was written ‚Äúvehikravtem‚Äù (and you shall offer), but in that of Rosh Hashanah, ‚Äúvaasitem‚Äù (and you shall do), to teach us that on this holy day we must make the sacrifice of our own being.
LEYES Y COSTUMBRES
Laws and Customs
Quien escribe una carta a un compa√±ero a partir del mes de Elul, debe mencionar en el principio, que le desea un ‚Äúa√±o nuevo bueno‚Äù.
Anyone who writes a letter to a friend starting in the month of Elul should mention at the beginning that they wish them a ‚Äúgood new year.‚Äù
No es nuestra costumbre rezar los Selijot antes de la medianoche o durante el oficio de la noche (Arvit). El rav Azulay calific√≥ esta costumbre de ‚Äúmala y amarga‚Äù (ver lo que escribi√≥ en Birke Yosef, O.J. 581,1).
It is not our custom to recite Seli·∏•ot before midnight or during the evening service (Arvit). Rav Azulay described this custom as ‚Äúbad and bitter‚Äù (see what he wrote in Birke Yosef, O.H. 581,1).
Durante el mes de Elul examinan los Tefilin, Mezuzot, y otros objetos religiosos para ver si est√°n de acuerdo con la Ley.
During the month of Elul, Tefillin, Mezuzot, and other religious objects are examined to see if they comply with the Law.
Antes de los Yamim Noraim es obligaci√≥n del que tiene ofrecido alg√∫n donativo al Templo, etc., o que est√° atrasado en sus pagos, liquidarlos, puesto que no se debe entrar a estas fiestas santas con deudas sagradas.
Before the Yamim Noraim, it is the obligation of those who have offered a donation to the Temple, etc., or who are behind in their payments, to settle them, since one should not enter these holy days with sacred debts.
Nuestra costumbre es hacer “Hatarat Nedarim” (anulaci√≥n de votos y promesas) en la v√≠spera de Rosh Hashan√° despu√©s de los “Selijot”. Pero ed necesario comprender el sentido de las palabras de este ritual y su significado. Por es explicamos su contenido en este libro.
Our custom is to perform ‚ÄúHatarat Nedarim‚Äù (annulment of vows and promises) on the eve of Rosh Hashanah after the ‚ÄúSeli·∏•ot.‚Äù However, it is necessary to understand the meaning of the words of this ritual and their significance. That is why we explain its content in this book.
ERUV TAVSHILIN. Cuando Rosh Hashan√° ocurre en jueves, es preciso hacer el mi√©rcoles ‚ÄúEruv Tavshilin‚Äù (mezcla de comidas), que es una ceremonia ritual para poder preparar el viernes 2¬∞ d√≠a de Rosh Hashan√°, las comidas para el s√°bado, d√≠a sagrado en que no se debe cocinar. Para esto es bueno consultar previamente al rabino de la Comunidad.
ERUV TAVSHILIN. When Rosh Hashanah falls on a Thursday, it is necessary to perform the ‚ÄúEruv Tavshilin‚Äù (mixing of foods) ritual on Wednesday, which is a ritual ceremony to prepare meals for Saturday, the holy day on which cooking is not permitted, on Friday, the second day of Rosh Hashanah. It is advisable to consult with the community rabbi beforehand.
VELAS. Al encender las velas en la v√≠spra de Rosh Hashan√° por la tarde, por lo menos media hora antes de la puesta del sol, la se√±ora de la casa debe pronunciar las bendiciones siguientes:
 
BARUJ ATA ADONAY, ELOHENU MELEJ HAOLAM, ASHER KIDESHANU BEMITZVOTAV, VETZIVANU LEHADLIK NER SHEL (SHABBAT VE) YOM TOV.
 
BARUJ ATA ADONAY, ELOHENU MELEJ HAOLAM, SHEEJEYANU VEKIYEMANU VEHIGUIANU LAZEMAN HAZE.
CANDLES. When lighting the candles on the eve of Rosh Hashanah in the evening, at least half an hour before sunset, the lady of the house should recite the following blessings:
 
BARUCH ATA ADONAI, ELOHENU MELECHE HAOLAM, ASHER KIDESHANU BEMITZVOTAV, VETZIVANU LEHADLIK NER SHEL (SHABBAT VE) YOM TOV.
 
BARUJ ATA ADONAY, ELOHENU MELEJ HAOLAM, SHEEJEYANU VEKIYEMANU VEHIGUIANU LAZEMAN HAZE.
ARVIT. Se comienza con AJOT KETANA, LAMNATZEAJ, KADISH, BAREJU, ETC. En la segunda noche el Arvit comienza con LAMNATZEAJ, ETC.
ARVIT. It begins with A·∏§OT QETANAH, LAMNATZEA·∏§, QADISH, BAREKHU, ETC. On the second night, Arvit begins with LAMNATZEA·∏§, ETC.
KIDUSH. Comienza con UVYOM SIMJATJEM, ETC., y al final se dice SHEEJEYANU. En la segunda noche de Rosh Haashan√° se dice tambi√©n SHEEJEYANU en el Kidush.
QIDUSH. It begins with UVYOM SIM·∏§ATKHEM, ETC., and at the end SHEHE·∏§EYANU is said. On the second night of Rosh HaShanah, SHEHE·∏§EYANU is also said in the Qidush.
Cayendo Rosh Hashan√° en s√°bado el Kidush comienza con Yom Hashishi, etc., y no se debe decir Zijron Teru√° Beahav√° Mikr√° K√≥desh sino Zijron Teru√° Mikr√° K√≥desh, puesto que Rosh Hashan√° es un d√≠a de juicio y austeridad y no es adecuado decir beahav√° (con amor), lo que no acontece con las fiestas de P√©saj, Shavuot y Sucot que son fiestas alegres.
Since Rosh Hashanah falls on Saturday, Kiddush begins with Yom Hashishi, etc., and one should not say Zikhron Teruah Beahavah Miqr√° Q√≥desh but rather Zikhron Teru√°h Miqr√° Q√≥desh, since Rosh Hashanah is a day of judgment and austerity and it is not appropriate to say beahav√°h (with love), which is not the case with the holidays of Passover, Shavuot, and Sukkot, which are joyful holidays.
Los ‚ÄúYEHI RATZON‚Äù: Antes de la cena de Rosh-Hashan√°, se dicen los ‚ÄúYEHI RATZON‚Äù comiendo manzana untada de miel, o dulce de manzana tambi√©n: poro, acelga, d√°tiles, calabaza, granada o pescado, cabeza de carnero, de ave o de pescado, que son cosas que por el nombre que llevan, y por el pensamiento con que las comemos, traen buena suerte en el nuevo a√±o. En la segunda noche se trate de comer un fruto nuevo sofre el cual se puede decir SHEEJEYANU. (Ver comentario en su lugar).
The ‚ÄúYEHI RATSON‚Äù: Before the Rosh Hashanah dinner, the ‚ÄúYEHI RATSON‚Äù are said while eating apples coated with honey, or apple jam: leeks, chard, dates, pumpkin, pomegranate, or fish, ram’s head, bird’s head, or fish head, which are things that, because of their names and the thoughts with which we eat them, bring good luck in the new year. On the second night, try to eat a new fruit over which you can say SHEHE·∏§EYANU. (See comment in its place).
TASHLIJ‚Äî En el primer d√≠a RoshHashan√° (cayendo √©ste en s√°bado, en el segundo d√≠a) despu√©s de ocraci√≥n de la tarde (Minj√°), se va al mar, o al r√≠i, o al lago, o cerca de una fuente de agua, y se reza el TASHLIJ, oraci√≥n para purificarse de los pecados. (Ver comentario en su lugar).
TASHLIKH‚Äî On the first day of Rosh Hashanah (which falls on Saturday, on the second day) after afternoon prayer (Min·∏•ah), one goes to the sea, or to a river, or to a lake, or near a water source, and recites TASHLIKH, a prayer to purify oneself of sins. (See commentary in its place).
No se debe dormir en Rosh-Hashan√° durante el d√≠a. Nuestros sabios dijeron que duerme la suerte de quien duerme en los d√≠as de Rosh-Hashan√°.
One should not sleep during the day on Rosh Hashanah. Our sages said that the luck of those who sleep on Rosh Hashanah sleeps with them.
Es costumbre no comer en RoshHashan√° comidas agrias y amargas.
It is customary not to eat sour and bitter foods on Rosh Hashanah.
Es la obligaci√≥n para todo hombre y tradici√≥n para toda mujer israelitas, o√≠r el toque del shof√°r en los dos d√≠as de Rosh-Hashan√° (excepto cuando ocurre en s√°bado), pues simboliza el despertar del pueblo para la penitencia. En la ma√±ana, cuando el Tok√©a dice la bendici√≥n, todos deben prestar atenci√≥n a su significado (verlo en su logar apropiado) y responder Am√©n.
It is the obligation of every Israelite man and the tradition of every Israelite woman to hear the blowing of the shofar on the two days of Rosh Hashanah (except when it falls on a Sabbath), as it symbolizes the awakening of the people to repentance. In the morning, when the Toq√©a says the blessing, everyone should pay attention to its meaning (see it in its proper place) and respond Amen.
